content.title: Arterial Line Placement and Monitoring
content.summary: Arterial catheters provide continuous blood pressure monitoring and easy arterial blood gas sampling in hemodynamically unstable patients. Common sites include radial (preferred), femoral, and brachial arteries. Waveform analysis provides diagnostic information beyond systolic/diastolic pressures. Complications include thrombosis, infection, and bleeding. Proper zeroing, leveling, and maintenance prevent inaccurate readings.
key_points: Indications: Hemodynamic instability, frequent ABGs, inaccurate NIBP
Radial artery preferred: Accessible, collateral circulation (Allen test), low complication rate
Femoral artery: Larger, easier cannulation; higher infection risk
Waveform analysis: Dicrotic notch (aortic valve closure), pulse pressure variation (fluid responsiveness)
Zero at phlebostatic axis (4th ICS, mid-axillary); level with transducer
Complications: Thrombosis, hematoma, infection, distal ischemia (rare)
content.statement: Arterial lines enable continuous blood pressure monitoring and frequent blood sampling in critically ill patients, with radial artery as preferred site, proper transducer positioning for accuracy, and waveform analysis providing additional hemodynamic data.

explanation.intuition: An arterial line gives you a real-time blood pressure reading with every heartbeat. Unlike a cuff that squeezes periodically, you see the actual pressure wave - the upstroke when the heart contracts, the downstroke as it relaxes, and the little bump (dicrotic notch) when the aortic valve closes.
explanation.key_insight: The arterial waveform tells you more than just numbers. A narrow waveform with low dicrotic notch suggests vasoconstriction. A wide, bounding waveform suggests vasodilation. Pulse pressure variation with breathing predicts fluid responsiveness - if the systolic pressure swings big with ventilator breaths, the patient is likely volume responsive.
explanation.technical_details: Modified Allen test assesses collateral ulnar flow. Cannulation via direct puncture or Seldinger technique. Transducer must be zeroed to atmospheric pressure at phlebostatic axis. Arterial waveform components: systolic upstroke, peak systolic pressure, dicrotic notch, diastolic pressure. Normal waveform sharpens distally (peripheral amplification).

definitions_glossary.arterial_line: Catheter in artery for continuous BP monitoring and blood sampling
definitions_glossary.radial_artery: Preferred site; lateral wrist; collateral from ulnar artery
definitions_glossary.Allen_test: Assesses ulnar collateral flow before radial cannulation
definitions_glossary.dicrotic_notch: Waveform feature marking aortic valve closure
definitions_glossary.pulse_pressure: Difference between systolic and diastolic pressure
definitions_glossary.pulse_pressure_variation: PPV; respiratory variation predicting fluid responsiveness
definitions_glossary.phlebostatic_axis: Zero reference point; 4th ICS, mid-axillary line
definitions_glossary.transducer: Converts pressure to electrical signal for monitoring
definitions_glossary.damping: Loss of waveform fidelity from air, clot, or kinking
definitions_glossary.peripheral_amplification: Normal increase in pulse pressure at peripheral arteries
definitions_glossary.arterial_blood_gas: ABG; blood sample for pH, PO2, PCO2, bicarbonate

radial.location: Wrist, lateral to flexor carpi radialis
radial.Allen_test: Occlude both arteries, release ulnar, observe reperfusion <7 seconds

brachial.note: Limited collateral flow; use with caution

transducer_setup.zeroing: Open to air, zero to atmospheric pressure
transducer_setup.check: Square wave test (flush test) to assess system dynamics

abnormal_waveforms.overdamped: Blunted waveform; underestimates systolic; causes: air, clot, kink
abnormal_waveforms.underdamped: Exaggerated oscillations; overestimates systolic; causes: long tubing, cold patient

clinical_correlates.pulsus_paradoxus: >10 mmHg drop with inspiration; tamponade, severe asthma
clinical_correlates.PPV: >13% variation suggests fluid responsiveness in ventilated patients

thrombosis.prevention: Smallest catheter possible; remove when not needed

infection.rate: Lower than central lines (~2 per 1000 catheter-days)

distal_ischemia.signs: Pain, pallor, pulselessness distal to line

definition.@value: Catheter placed in artery for continuous blood pressure monitoring and blood gas sampling

scopeNote.@value: Radial preferred; waveform provides hemodynamic information beyond numbers

learning_objectives: Describe indications for arterial line placement
clinical_pearls: Radial preferred - do Allen test for collateral flow
Zero at phlebostatic axis (4th ICS, mid-axillary)
Overdamped = blunted wave; underdamped = ringing oscillations
PPV >13% predicts fluid responsiveness in ventilated patients
Dicrotic notch disappears in severe hypotension
common_misconceptions: Allen test must be perfect before radial cannulation - clinical judgment applies
Art line always more accurate than cuff - can be inaccurate if damped
Femoral is equivalent - higher infection rate than radial
